questions.question_text: Which two statements are true about SQL *Loader Express Mode in an Oracle 12c database? (Choose two.)

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: AC
For A,
https://docs.oracle.com/database/121/SUTIL/GUID-B3EAC57A-3AEB-42F9-9438-4CB077BF7383.htm#SUTIL3978
If AUTO is used, then the Oracle database automatically sets the degree of parallelism for the load. This is also the default if the DEGREE_OF_PARALLELISM parameter is not specified at all.

choices.D: You can have multiple bad files created when loading in parallel.
choices.E: You can selectively load rows into a table based on a filter.
choices.B: You cannot have multiple SQL *Loader data files.
choices.C: If no data file is specified, it assumes the data file to be <table-name>.dat in the current directory and uses it.
choices.A: The DEGREE_OF_PARALLELISM parameter is set to AUTO.

questions.question_text:
You install "Oracle Grid Infrastructure for a standalone server" on a host on which the ORCL1 and ORCL2 databases both have their instances running.
Which two statements are true? (Choose two.)

discussion.content:
AB must be the answer. Explanation is below.
https://docs.oracle.com/cd/E18283_01/server.112/e17120/restart002.htm#CIHFEHDH
If you install Oracle Restart by installing the Oracle Grid Infrastructure for a standalone server and then create your database, the database is automatically added to the Oracle Restart configuration, and is then automatically restarted when required. 

However, if you install Oracle Restart on a host computer on which a database already exists, you must manually add the database, the listener, the Oracle Automatic Storage Management (Oracle ASM) instance, and possibly other components to the Oracle Restart configuration.

Selected Answer: AB
https://docs.oracle.com/cd/E18283_01/server.112/e17120/restart002.htm#CIHFEHDH

If you install Oracle Restart by installing the Oracle Grid Infrastructure for a standalone server and then create your database, the database is automatically added to the Oracle Restart configuration, and is then automatically restarted when required. However, if you install Oracle Restart on a host computer on which a database already exists, you must manually add the database, the listener, the Oracle Automatic Storage Management (Oracle ASM) instance, and possibly other components to the Oracle Restart configuration.

choices.C: Both ORCL1 and ORCL2 are automatically added to the Oracle Restart configuration.
choices.A: All databases subsequently created by using the Database Configuration Assistant (DBCA) are automatically added to the Oracle Restart configuration.
choices.E: The crsctl start has command must be used to start software services for Oracle Automatic Storage Management (ASM) after the "Oracle Grid
choices.B: The srvctl add database command must be used to add ORCL1 and ORCL2 to the ORACLE Restart configuration.
choices.D: All database listeners running from the database home are automatically added to the Oracle Restart configuration.

discussion.content: Connecting to database with sqlplus locally does not need listener at all, so I think AB is correct.

comments.content: Option E mentions a client, not local connection: A connection request from a client
One listener can be used by multiple databases

choices.C: The listener continuously monitors a connection after the user process connects to a service handler.
choices.B: A server process checks a userâ€™s authentication credentials and creates a session if the credentials are valid.
choices.E: A connection request from a client is always first received by a listener running on the port that is used for the connection request for the database server.
choices.D: The listener always spawns a new server process to deal with each new connection.
choices.A: A listener may listen on behalf of only one database instance at a time.

questions.question_text: Which two statements are true about Oracle network connections? (Choose two.)

choices.D: It can generate unique sequential key values in specified columns.
choices.A: It can load data from external files by using the direct path only.
choices.C: It can load data into only one table at a time.
choices.E: It can load data from external files by using the conventional path only.
choices.B: It can load data into multiple tables using the same load statement.

questions.question_text: Which two statements are true about using SQL*Loader? (Choose two.)

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: BD
BD is the answer
http://www.dba-oracle.com/t_sql_loader_multiple_tables_sqlldr.htm

Selected Answer: AD
B is not correct because we cannot load data into multiple tables using same load statement (it can be done in same load session)
A is not entirely correct.
Apart from option D, none of the options are entirely correct.

#143
C. Load data into multiple tables during the same load statement.
D. Generate unique sequential key values in specified columns.

A: DB_RECOVERY_FILE_DEST specifies the default location for the flash recovery area. The flash recovery area contains multiplexed copies of current control files and online redo logs, as well as archived redo logs, flashback logs, and RMAN backups.
In order to specify a different location for storing archive logs, we need to specify the same unnder log_archive_dest_1 parameter.

choices.A: It executes successfully and sets the Fast Recovery Area as the local archive destination.
choices.D: It executes successfully and sets $ORACLE_HOME/dbs as the default archive destination.
choices.C: It fails and returns an error about LOG_ARCHIVE_DEST not being set.
choices.B: It executes successfully and issues a warning to set LOG_ARCHIVE_DEST while opening the database.
